algebraic.dist: Examples

Source: vignettes/example.Rmd
example.Rmd

Introduction

To demonstrate the R package algebraic.dist, we consider the multivariate normal distribution (MVN) and its empirical approximation.

We start by loading the package:

library(algebraic.dist)

Defining the data generating process

We define the parameters of the data generating process (DGP) with:

# we define the parameters of the MVN
M <- mvn(mu    = 1:5, sigma = diag(1:5))
print(M)
#> Multivariate normal distribution with mean:
#> [1] 1 2 3 4 5
#> and variance-covariance matrix:
#>      [,1] [,2] [,3] [,4] [,5]
#> [1,]    1    0    0    0    0
#> [2,]    0    2    0    0    0
#> [3,]    0    0    3    0    0
#> [4,]    0    0    0    4    0
#> [5,]    0    0    0    0    5

Each observation is an i.i.d. vector from the MVN. We sample from the MVN with:

# we generate a sample of size n
n <- 100000

# we sample from the MVN
data <- sampler(M)(n)

We have a sample of size \(n=10^{5}\) from the DGP. We show some observations from this sample with:

head(data, n=6)
#>        [,1]   [,2] [,3]   [,4] [,5]
#> [1,]  0.314  2.460 4.74  3.153 5.17
#> [2,]  0.356 -0.124 1.84  3.593 5.72
#> [3,] -0.415  0.960 3.31  2.720 3.37
#> [4,]  0.299  1.074 2.44  2.413 8.82
#> [5,] -0.451  0.250 4.30 -0.238 4.61
#> [6,]  1.061  0.489 4.20  3.897 5.52

Now, we also construct a empirical distribution from the sample with:

emp <- empirical_dist(data)
print(emp)
#> Empirical Distribution 
#> Mean:
#> [1] 1.00 1.99 3.00 4.00 5.00
#> Covariance:
#>           [,1]     [,2]     [,3]      [,4]     [,5]
#> [1,]  1.007719 -0.00238  0.00364  0.000178  0.00877
#> [2,] -0.002379  1.99862 -0.00645  0.016907 -0.00942
#> [3,]  0.003644 -0.00645  2.99783  0.009765  0.02244
#> [4,]  0.000178  0.01691  0.00977  4.018779 -0.01714
#> [5,]  0.008769 -0.00942  0.02244 -0.017136  5.04388
#> Number of observations: 100000

Letâ€™s show the supports of the empirical distribution and the MVN:

# generate a data frame with the dimension, supremum,
# and infimum of the MVN and empirical distribution
df <- data.frame(supremum.mvn = supremum(sup(M)),
                 supremum.emp = supremum(sup(emp)),
                 infimum.mvn = infimum(sup(M)),
                 infimum.emp = infimum(sup(emp)))
row.names(df) <- paste0("param",1:dim(sup(M)))
print(df)
#>        supremum.mvn supremum.emp infimum.mvn infimum.emp
#> param1          Inf         5.04        -Inf       -3.25
#> param2          Inf         8.15        -Inf       -3.87
#> param3          Inf        11.50        -Inf       -4.14
#> param4          Inf        12.52        -Inf       -5.39
#> param5          Inf        16.00        -Inf       -4.58

Letâ€™s compare the mean and covariance-variance matrices of both the MVN and the empirical distribution of the MVN. First, letâ€™s look at the means.

mean(M)
#> [1] 1 2 3 4 5
mean(emp)
#> [1] 1.00 1.99 3.00 4.00 5.00

As expected, pretty close. Now letâ€™s look at the variance-covariance:

vcov(M)
#>      [,1] [,2] [,3] [,4] [,5]
#> [1,]    1    0    0    0    0
#> [2,]    0    2    0    0    0
#> [3,]    0    0    3    0    0
#> [4,]    0    0    0    4    0
#> [5,]    0    0    0    0    5
vcov(emp)
#>           [,1]     [,2]     [,3]      [,4]     [,5]
#> [1,]  1.007719 -0.00238  0.00364  0.000178  0.00877
#> [2,] -0.002379  1.99862 -0.00645  0.016907 -0.00942
#> [3,]  0.003644 -0.00645  2.99783  0.009765  0.02244
#> [4,]  0.000178  0.01691  0.00977  4.018779 -0.01714
#> [5,]  0.008769 -0.00942  0.02244 -0.017136  5.04388

The true variances of the population defined by the MVN \(M\) is the diagonal of the variance-covariance matrix:

diag(vcov(M))
#> [1] 1 2 3 4 5

Letâ€™s compute the variances using the general expectation method:

mu.emp <- mean(emp)
expectation(emp, function(x) (x - mu.emp)^2)
#> [1] 1.01 2.00 3.00 4.02 5.04
expectation(M, function(x) (x - mean(M))^2, control = list(n = n))
#> [1] 0.997 2.003 3.013 3.972 5.002

We see that these are pretty good estimates, as the expectation is actually a Monte Carlo approximation. We can see the CIâ€™s with:

expectation(emp, function(x) (x - mu.emp)^2, control = list(compute_stats = TRUE))
#> $value
#> [1] 1.01 2.00 3.00 4.02 5.04
#> 
#> $ci
#>       [,1] [,2]
#> [1,] 0.999 1.02
#> [2,] 1.981 2.02
#> [3,] 2.972 3.02
#> [4,] 3.983 4.05
#> [5,] 5.000 5.09
#> 
#> $n
#> [1] 100000
expectation(M, function(x) (x - mean(M))^2, control = list(n = n, compute_stats = TRUE))
#> $value
#> [1] 1.00 2.00 3.00 4.00 4.98
#> 
#> $ci
#>       [,1] [,2]
#> [1,] 0.993 1.01
#> [2,] 1.985 2.02
#> [3,] 2.977 3.03
#> [4,] 3.968 4.04
#> [5,] 4.941 5.03
#> 
#> $n
#> [1] 100000

Next, we use the rmap function on the MVN and the empirical distribution to compute the distribution of \((X - E(X))^2\). If we take the mean of this, we should get the variance as shown above:

mu.emp <- mean(emp)
mean(rmap(emp, function(x) (x - mu.emp)^2))
#> [1] 1.01 2.00 3.00 4.02 5.04
mean(rmap(M, function(x) (x - mean(M))^2, n = n))
#> [1] 1.01 2.01 3.01 4.00 4.95

These are both reasonable estimates of the variance.

The PDF of the empirical is not very useful â€“ it gets \(1/n\) for each observation:

x <- sampler(emp)(1)
y <- sampler(M)(1)
data.frame(
  ob = c("empirical(x)", "MVN(y)"),
  pdf.emp = c(pdf(emp)(x), pdf(emp)(y)),
  pdf.mvn = c(pdf(M)(x), pdf(M)(y)))
#>             ob pdf.emp  pdf.mvn
#> 1 empirical(x)   1e-05 0.000409
#> 2       MVN(y)   0e+00 0.000426

Letâ€™s plot the CDF of marginal distribution of \(X_1\):

X1.emp <- marginal(emp, 1)
F1.emp <- cdf(X1.emp)
curve(F1.emp(x), from = infimum(sup(X1.emp)), to = supremum(sup(X1.emp)), col = "blue", lty = 1)
X1 <- marginal(M, 1)
F1 <- cdf(X1)
curve(F1(x), from = infimum(sup(X1.emp)), to = supremum(sup(X1.emp)), add = TRUE, col = "red", lty = 2)
legend("topleft", legend = c("empirical", "MVN"), col = c("blue", "red"), lty = c(1, 2))

Given the sample size, the empirical distributionâ€™s CDF is essentially the same as the MVNâ€™s CDF (theyâ€™re right on top of each other). Letâ€™s zoom in much closer so we can ee that the empirical CDF is a step function:

curve(F1.emp(x), from = 1, to = 1.0005, col = "blue", lty = 1, type = "s")

Letâ€™s compute some expectations of \(X_1\):

cat("E(X1) = ", expectation(X1, \(x) x), "( expected ", mean(X1), ")\n",
"Var(X1) = ", expectation(X1, \(x)
  (x - expectation(X1, \(x) x))^2), "( expected ", vcov(X1), ")\n",
"Skewness(X1) = ", expectation(X1, function(x)
  (x - expectation(X1, \(x) x))^3) / expectation(X1, \(x) x)^3, "( expected 0 )\n",
"E(X^2) = ", expectation(X1, \(x) x^2), "( expected ", vcov(X1) + mean(X1)^2, ")")
#> E(X1) =  1 ( expected  1 )
#>  Var(X1) =  1 ( expected  1 )
#>  Skewness(X1) =  -3.41e-13 ( expected 0 )
#>  E(X^2) =  2 ( expected  2 )

Letâ€™s show a scatter plot of the joint distribution of \(X_2\) and \(X_4\):

dataX2X4.emp <- sampler(marginal(emp, c(2, 4)))(10000)
dataX2X4.mvn <- sampler(marginal(M, c(2, 4)))(10000)

# scatter plot a 2d sample. use xlab and ylab to label the axes
plot(dataX2X4.emp[,1], dataX2X4.emp[,2], pch = 20, col = "blue", xlab = "X2", ylab = "X4")
# overlay in green the MVN data
points(dataX2X4.mvn[,1], dataX2X4.mvn[,2], pch = 20, col = "green")
legend("topright", legend = c("empirical", "MVN"), col = c("blue", "green"), pch = c(20, 20))
title("Scatter plot of X2 and X4")

Letâ€™s look at the MVNâ€™s multivariate CDF:

cdf(M)(c(1,2,3,4,0))
#> [1] 0.000792

Now we show the mean of the conditional distribution, \(X | X_1 + X_2 < 0\):

mean(conditional(emp, function(x) x[1] + x[2] < 0))
#> [1] -0.237 -0.458  3.010  4.002  5.003
mean(conditional(M, function(x) x[1] + x[2] < 0))
#> [1] -0.248 -0.507  3.032  3.992  5.231

I didnâ€™t do the analysis of what this distributionâ€™s mean should theoretically be, if itâ€™s even practical to derive, but it doesnâ€™t look unreasonble. We see that the mean of the first two components are negative, which makes sense: the sum of the first two components is negative, so the mean of the first two components should be negative.
